title: Frequency and period - springs X and Y with graph

content.question: Two springs, Spring <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> and Spring <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math>, are hung vertically and four different metal cylinders of known mass are attached to the bottom of each spring, one at a time. The oscillation period of each cylinder-spring combination is then determined, and the data are used to make a graph of the square of the period versus the cylinder mass, as shown. How are the spring constants <math alttext="k sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="k sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math> related?

choices.label: <math alttext="k sub Y equals the fraction k sub X over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mn>4</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="k sub Y equals the fraction k sub X over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="k sub Y equals 2 k sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="k sub Y equals 4 k sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="k sub Y equals 2 k sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
